definition:
A logic is said to be $(\kappa,\lambda)$-compact, if the following holds

> If $\Phi$ is a set of sentences of cardinality less than or equal to
> $\kappa$ and all subsets of $\Phi$ of cardinality less than $\lambda$
> are consistent, then $\Phi$ is consistent.

For example, first order logic is $(\omega,\omega)$-compact, for if all
finite subsets of some class of sentences are consistent, so is the
class itself.
